Good points!
But then we are talking about REST constrains to achieve REST =
goals, in an architecture. That is true. But REST does not say you can't bu=
ild systems any other way, and does not say any other system may not commun=
icate with you. What it says is, you need to talk to me this way to achieve=
 this. If I talk differently, then I put in jeopardy that goal. Maybe the s=
entence is badly formulated, or read out of context sounds like there is no=
 constrain.

What I mean is you follow REST constrains to get REST goals, i=
f there are things that are not perfect, you loose a little. But with any a=
rchitectural style, you may need to combine.

It may be a good discussion o=
f whether REST badge may be removed if there is just one non-complaint comp=
onent in the system. When I think of SOA, I'm perfectly aware that not all =
components are going to be services, that won't make it less SOA for that. =
We can make the same analysis with REST. Don't you think?

William.
